back: Typography is the art of choosing the right fonts and format to make text visually appealing and easy to read.
A typeface is the overall design and style of a set of characters, numbers, and symbols.
A font is a specific variation of a typeface with characteristics like size, weight, style, and width.
A serif typeface has small lines at the ends of characters and is commonly used in print materials.
A sans-serif typeface has no small lines at the ends of characters and is commonly used in digital design.
Font weight describes the thickness of the characters, such as light, regular, bold, and black.
Font style refers to the slant and orientation of characters, such as italic and oblique.
Font width is the horizontal space characters occupy, such as condensed or expanded.

front: What is the baseline in typography?
back: The baseline is the imaginary line on which most characters rest.
Cap height is the height of uppercase letters, measured from the baseline to the top.
X-height is the average height of lowercase letters, excluding ascenders and descenders.
Ascenders are parts of lowercase letters that extend above the x-height, like in 'h', 'b', 'd', and 'f'.
Descenders are parts of lowercase letters that extend below the baseline, like in 'y', 'g', 'p', and 'q'.
Kerning adjusts space between specific character pairs to improve readability and aesthetics.
Tracking adjusts the spacing between all characters in a block of text.
Leading is the vertical space between lines of text, measured from one baseline to the next.

front: What are best practices for typography?
back: Choose clear, simple fonts to make text easy to read, especially for main content.
A font family is a group of fonts with the same design, and you can specify fallbacks using commas.

front: Name some common CSS font families.
back: serif, sans-serif, monospace, cursive, fantasy
Fonts likely to be installed on most devices, used as fallbacks when a preferred font isn't available.
Statements that give instructions to the browser, such as @media, @keyframes, or @font-face.
@font-face defines a custom font by specifying the font file, format, and properties like weight and style.

front: What does the src property in @font-face do?
back: It specifies the location of font resources such as .woff or .otf files.

front: What is the difference between woff and woff2?
back: woff2 uses a more efficient compression algorithm than woff.

front: How do you include external fonts using a link element?
back: Use <link> in your HTML head with the font URL from services like Google Fonts.

front: How do you include external fonts using @import?
back: Use @import with a URL inside your CSS to load fonts from external sources.

front: What does the text-shadow property do?
back: It applies shadow effects to text using X and Y offsets, blur, and color.

front: What happens if you don't specify a shadow color in text-shadow?
back: The browser will automatically determine the color, which may not be ideal.

front: What does the blur radius in text-shadow control?
back: It makes the shadow smoother; higher values increase blur and lighten the shadow.
